thread.title: Liberal Democrats snatch second Sunderland council seat in by-election
thread.title_full: Liberal Democrats snatch second Sunderland council seat in by-election

author: Sean Seddon
title: Liberal Democrats snatch second Sunderland council seat in by-election
text:
Share this video Watch Next 
Labour failed to convince voters to back their decades-long stewardship of the city even on a voter turnout of 23.8%. 
Speaking at the count at Thorney Close Primary School 26-year-old Coun O’Brien, said: “We got our just deserts. 
“We’ve been working hard for three months and we’ve got a message which connects with people in this area. 
“The council need to re-connect with the people of Sunderland.” 
Despite the ongoing Brexit row Coun O’Brien said the Lib Dems fought the by-election on local issues – sidelining Europe. 
Buoyed by a young, enthusiastic team which was roundly praised by members of competing parties, the Lib Dems surprised Labour with an organised and well-manned ground game. 
Councillor Paul Watson, Labour leader of Sunderland City Council, said: “We’ve got a very young Lib Dem team in the city and they put the time, effort and hard yards in terms of door-knocking.” 
Despite having dozens of people involved in a last ditch push to get voters to the polls on Thursday, Labour slumped. 
The by-election was triggered following the departure of Labour councillor Jacqui Gallagher. Read More Liberal Democrats are winning in the North East, says party leader Tim Farron 
She automatically forfeited her seat because she failed to attend a single council meeting for six months. 
Coun Watson admitted the result was a concern, said: “We need to take note of what the electorate have said.” 
Labour’s candidate, Gary Waller, refused to comment following the result and before the result was announced Mr Waller refused to shake the soon-to-be Coun O’Brien’s hand. 
UKIP candidate Bryan Foster, also praised the Lib Dem’s election strategy and blamed the bitingly cold weather for the low turnout. 
Asked whether he was concerned at the lack of electoral breakthrough for UKIP despite the massive support for Brexit in the city, he said: “You always have to hope it’s going to come through at some point. 
“I think our party’s problems in the summer unsettled people but I’m sure our new leader will re-build the party again.” 
Full results: 
Bryan George Foster - UKIP: 343 
Helmut Izaks - Green: 23 
Stephen Francis O’Brien - Lib Dem: 824 
Gary Edward Waller - Labour: 458 
Gavin William Christopher Wilson - Con: 184 
Total votes cast: 1,832
